episode.title: Good News Club v. Milford Central School

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now on number 99-2036.
Good News Club v. Milford Central School.
Mr. Marcelle.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court--
This is a free speech case.

On page 13 of its brief in opposition to certiorari, Milford concedes that State law, the same State law at issue in Lamb's Chapel, requires it to censor petitioner's speech from its broad community forums at all times, to all audiences because they had a religious purpose.
This Court rejected such an argument in Lamb's Chapel.
It should reject it in this case as well.
The Second Circuit circumvented this Court's decision in Lamb's Chapel by resurrecting a distinction that this Court buried in Widmar.
A distinction between constitutionally protected speech and unconstitutionally protected religious worship and instruction.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Marcelle, did you cite Lamb's Chapel to the Second Circuit?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, quite extensively, and dissent as well said, Judge Jacobs said the case couldn't be squared with Lamb's Chapel.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Lamb's Chapel, if I'm correct, is not even cited in the Second Circuit's opinion, is that right?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Isn't even mentioned?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Isn't even mentioned.
And I think the way they got around Lamb's Chapel, Your Honor, was really by embracing a distinction that this Court rejected in Rosenberger, a distinction--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I assume that the judge who wrote the opinion for the Second Circuit was aware of Lamb's Chapel, not just because you cited it, but because it had reversed an earlier decision of his, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.
He was the author of Lamb's Chapel that this Court reversed.
And I think the way--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Marcelle, could you clarify for us the nature of the right that you are asserting.
Now, could the school district say we are not going to allow access to any groups in off school hours?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --Absolutely.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And you contend that the school has, instead of doing that, opened a limited public forum allowing some groups to use the school in off hours?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Could the school say only hours after 6 p.m.?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Your Honor, yes, they--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And only certain days a week?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
They have broad discretion, the school board--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You're just seeking equal access on the same terms that the school offers it to other groups to benefit the welfare of the community, is that the idea?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --Exactly, Justice O'Connor.
We're not asking for unique access, just equal access.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What if a church asks for privilege to conduct church services once a week during the hours the school allows?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Because, Your Honor, Milford has chosen to create a forum that it's probably the broadest possible forum you could create, the uses that pertain to the welfare of the community under this policy, I think they would a Mass, or a church service would qualify, but of course, they have the power and the discretion.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So if one of the local churches came in and said we'd like to use it one day a week to conduct our regular services, that would have to be granted as well, if it fell on a day and an hour when the school said it was open?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, under this policy.

Of course the school could write the policy to limit it to athletic, just athletic events or just theatrical events but they couldn't exclude religious groups or religious viewpoints on those subjects.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well but, I think you can say that the school, that the school couldn't exclude religious viewpoints or religious groups and still not necessarily say that it had to be open for a full dress religious service.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, that's correct.
I think again in this case Milford has drafted the broadest possible policy.
It's really when you say any social, civic or recreation use or other uses pertaining to the community you, I think, have created the broadest possible forum--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It specifically allows meetings and entertainment events and other uses.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --That's correct.
And I think the phrase is other uses that pertain to the welfare of the community, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Might there not be a problem with the establishment clause, apart from the viewpoint versus content discrimination if there were say a church service to be conducted the same time the Boy Scouts are meeting?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I don't believe so, Justice Ginsburg, for this reason.

When you choose, when you choose, as Milford has in this case, to shut its school down at 3 o'clock and thereby open up a public forum inside your school, you can't restrict religious viewpoints even if the viewpoint in the speech is exercise in a religious ceremony.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you are talking about a First Amendment free speech right.
That's how you open this.

There is also an issue that hasn't been aired in this case, and that is the issue that arose in Widmar and in Murgens, the distinction between, for establishment clause purposes, people of a certain sophistication versus younger people.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, I'll give you two answers to your inquiry.
One, I think this is like Widmar.

For example, in Widmar would essentially be the cornerstone group which was the student group that sought access to the school was a religious group singing religious songs, reading the Bible and praying, and this Court didn't find a constitutional problem in that case because it was--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: The age of the, the... that played some role in the Court's decision, didn't it?
That these were college students who had a degree of sophistication and could distinguish between just opening it up to everybody, and the school endorsing it?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --That's correct, Justice Ginsburg.

And in this case, in Widmar, the appropriate community was the students so you would look at the observer student, but in this case, Milford has ended school and has opened up a community forum for parents to initiate and parents to run these community groups.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What was at issue in Widmar?
What, what kind of activity?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: It was a... praying and reading the Bible and singing religious songs and teaching from the Bible.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: In, in the school or to the whole school body, before the whole school body?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Not before the whole school body, Your Honor.
Just to the participants who wanted to hear and chose to hear this message like this case.
The only children who attend the Good News Club are sent there by their parents.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And that was upheld?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: And that was upheld, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I'm sorry.
Isn't the nub of the problem in this case that you're not dealing with college students, you're dealing with grade school kids, kids from, I think it was ages starting at six going up to 12.
You're doing it... in this particular case, the meeting was being held immediately after the school and the meeting sounds to me as it was described as Sunday school.
They pray.

They sing sort of children's religious songs, and they have a teaching lesson and I guess some discussion, but it sounds like Sunday school, and isn't the problem in this case that you don't have a sophisticated group of people of college age who know that the university is not proselytizing them or approving of their particular religious practice, whereas in this case you have a bunch of kids who just don't make those kinds of distinctions, and isn't that the nub of the establishment clause problem here, which didn't exist in Widmar?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: If I may, Justice, be allowed to give you, kind of, two answers.
One, that's not the case because if this meeting was conducted at 9 o'clock at night and was given just to adults, State law would prohibit from them meeting under those circumstances.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, that, that might be the case, and it might be the case that you would have a different case before us if those were your facts, but whether State law would prohibit it or not, my question is, don't we have here at least a substantial, I won't decide it from the bench, but don't we have a substantial establishment clause issue, which we simply didn't have in Widmar so that you can't take Widmar as being direct authority for what was going on here?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I would say the answer... and that would be in the second part of my answer.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Right.
Get to number two.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --to your, to your question, is the parents are the ones who decide whether or not the children will attend.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He's worried about the other children who are, who are supposedly hanging around the school after the bell rings, instead of skipping off the way my kids do.
Actually, and they are infected by seeing these other kids going into an activity which they think represents the approval of the State for these religious services.
I think that's the point he's making.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I would never spurn Justice Scalia's help, but actually... actually, I think you understood my question.
Why don't you answer it as modified by Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I guess I would go back to Justice O'Connor's concurrence in Capitol Square where she said the endorsement tests and the establishment clause are concerned with the political community at large and not particular individuals or isolated observers.
Here the day ends and--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That's, that's, you know, that's because that was the group to which Capitol Plaza was appealing, but here, the appeal is to kids, and in particular, to the kids who are going to this Sunday school kind of service.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --I guess I would disagree with all respect, Justice Souter.
I think the appeal is to the parents.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Marcelle, was this the basis for the school's refusal to allow the group, you can't do it right after school?
Was that the--

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: No.
That was not the basis.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --And was this point raised before the Second Circuit?
Was it part of the Second Circuit's opinion?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Absolutely not.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Was the point raised before the Second Circuit?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: If I could search my memory and I don't believe, or if it was raised, it was raised tangentially, Your Honor.
It certainly wasn't the thrust.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well then, then do you feel that the decision that the judgment of the Second Circuit should be vacated and the case should be remanded for consideration of this issue?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Well, I, I think what happens is for the purpose of--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What do you, what do you think should happen?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --Excuse me.
I think this case should be reversed and remanded back to district court to grant the relief we requested.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And why, why should this issue not be considered in the Second Circuit?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I believe that Milford school had the burden of proof.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you were the Plaintiff in the case, and you had the First Amendment theory, and that lost, and you appealed on that theory.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Now, it would seem to me if the other issue was, was not aired, we should not decide it in the first instance.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, there was cross motions for summary judgment.

We moved for summary judgment and the school district moved for summary judgment, and to defeat our motion for summary judgment, they had the burden of proving a compelling State interest and that the censorship forum, from the forum was the least restrictive means to achieve that interest.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Marcelle, when the, when the State refuses somebody something to which he is entitled for the wrong reason, and the case is appealed up here, and we say that reason was wrong, do we normally, if the State comes in and says oh, we could have, we could have done it for another reason, you know, not because of his race.
We might have done it for some other reason, do we normally remand to give him a second bite?
Aren't they stuck with the reason that they gave?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Well, I think, they are stuck with the record as in any trial, on any appeal, you could raise new issues and new grounds and could have a new trial.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: This school said we will not let you conduct this service, period.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: At any time.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: At any time because we do not allow religious services in the school, and that's the basis on which it was argued below, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Did the Court of Appeals rely on the establishment clause in its decision?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: No, it did not, Mr. Chief Justice.
We were briefly, my recollection, questioned about it, but the Second Circuit did not rest its decision on that grounds.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And in a trial court, the school district made no distinction in its summary judgment motions or in its answer based on the fact that this was immediately after school?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I'm not sure--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The school district said it could bar these, it could bar these meetings at any time of day?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --That's correct.
And it's--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And it made no, and it made no distinction between right after school or an hour after school or two hours after school?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --That's correct, Justice Kennedy and in fact on the joint appendix at G 4 and I believe it's paragraph 13, it's the superintendent's affidavit where he is basically says that your speech is too religious to be using the forum.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Marcelle, does State law require this school district to open its facilities after school to other groups?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: No, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: This is a decision made by the particular school.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Yes.
New York State education law grants the power to the local school boards.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But does not require it.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: But does not require it.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And is it clear under State law that the school could adopt whatever provisions it wants for its opening of the school?
It could choose to limit it to athletic purposes at certain hours and on certain days?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Yes.
What State law sets a ceiling for what school districts can do, and they can go, the floor goes to not even opening the forum and they can go anywhere in between.
Here, Milford chose to, the maximum possible extent allowed under, under--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So it would be entirely open, whatever this Court chose to do for the school to revamp its policy for hours and days and purposes?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --Absolutely, Justice O'Connor.
New York grants them broad discretion and the school board has that ability to exercise that discretion.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask, what is the, is there a State statutory ceiling you say?
In other words, is there a State limit on how much religious activity they could permit?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Yes, Justice Stevens.
It's State--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Are you challenging both the school board's regulation and the State statute?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --They gave both reasons for denial, and--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And I'm asking, are you challenging--

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --I'm sorry, yes, Justice Stevens.
We are challenging both.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --So you are contending the statute is unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: The statute to the extent... Justice Stevens, actually it requires a little explanation under New York law.
It really isn't that, the history in New York law is a little more entangled.
The State legislature had opened up it for these broad purposes if the school board so chose.

In 1978, there was a mid level appellate court in the State that was decided prior to Murgens that said because the State legislature didn't specifically include religious purposes in the statute, the court interpreted as it meant to exclude religious purposes, although the State doesn't, the statute doesn't say that, that has become part of the judicial interpretation of the statute, so I don't want to mislead you and it's contained in the statute, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, I want to know how that explanation that you just gave us fits with, with what you were telling Justice O'Connor a moment ago.

If you win this case, and the school board says we want to revamp our regulations, and our regulations are going to be that although religious purposes do not exclude a group from, from use of the facilities, religious worship does, and we are going to draw the line there, or they might say we are going to draw the line against any use that could be regarded reasonably as an establishment clause violation when young kids are involved.

Would you take the position then that because you think the, the New York statute is unconstitutional that the school district could not draw that restriction or either of those restrictions that I have just described, and which if the statute is unconstitutional does it render the school district in fact, in this respect, does it render the school district incapable of drawing any distinction whatever that has any reference to religion?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I believe Widmar answers that question, Justice Souter.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I would like Marcelle to answer that question.
What position, what's your argument?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: My argument is religious worship is inherently a religious viewpoint.
In other words, when I say hail Mary full of grace and say amen, that's my internal attitude.
If I say ha ha, I'm allowed in the forum, but if I say amen, I'm excluded and it seems to me what makes one worship and the other not worship is my internal attitude.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No.
But... is, you are saying that the State cannot exclude what's going on... that the district could not exclude what's going on here.
But is it because the statute is itself unconstitutional in drawing a religious distinction?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: No.
I believe it's unconstitutional under the free speech clause.
That is, the State cannot exclude religious viewpoints from a forum that otherwise speaks on the subject matter.
For example, in this case--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
No.

I don't, I don't mean to cut you off, but I just wonder, you answered Justice O'Connor's question, as I recall, by saying yes, the State could go back and revamp the policy and draw it more narrowly, and I understood you to say, or to imply that if it wanted to draw a policy that says no religious worship involving young kids or something like that, that, that would be open to it and I want to know whether your position on the statute leads you to say no, the school district would not be, even without State, would be without State authority under State law even to do that.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --My position is that the First Amendment prohibits drawing that distinction, if that, whatever you called the worship fits within the otherwise religious neutral boundaries of the forum.
So, for example--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But is that because the State statute is simply inoperative to give the school districts the authority to redraw a policy more narrowly?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --No.
I think the limitation on the school board is the First Amendment to the United States Constitution.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: If there were to be an action, let's say you prevailed in this action, there would be an action by parents of a 6 year old attending this school, that would challenge the allowance of this group on establishment clause grounds, that would in no way be foreclosed by this, this decision if the issue is there, but not decided by this case, is that right?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I guess that would be correct, Justice Ginsburg.
I mean, I guess cases can't stand for propositions which aren't decided in them, and I think that's--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So the whole question one way or another of whether elementary school students are differently situated than high school students or college students would be open in any case?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --Depending how the court wrote the opinion, yes.
Yes.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I mean the establishment clause has been presented in this case at least as a defense, that is to say, it has been alleged that one of the reasons that the State could do this is because of the establishment clause problems that would arise were they to do it, and it is, it is quite possibly for this Court's opinion to address that establishment clause argument as well, isn't it?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I would assume it's quite possible, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I'm confused.
I thought you said it wasn't raised.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I'm sorry, I said that, excuse me, Justice Ginsburg.
I think what I was trying to say in response to Justice Souter's question was they hadn't met their burden.
It's different between, I think, not raising it and not meeting the burden of proof of showing a compelling stage.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But wasn't there a position below, maybe, maybe I misunderstood what you were saying, but I thought their position below was that any use for a religious purpose, any, as you were putting it, any expression of a religious point of view on the subjects that might be discussed could be excluded and that was the reason for excluding this.
Is that so?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Souter.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And do you, do you believe that, that if we say no, that's too broad a ground, that they would then be foreclosed from redrawing their policy on a narrower ground based upon avoidance of an establishment clause problem if they do allow this, would they be--

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I'm not sure.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Would they be precluded?
In other words, they are saying okay, we can't paint with a broad brush.
We are going to paint with a narrow brush.
We are going to say this would be a violation of the establishment clause to allow a Sunday school kind of worship for young school kids immediately after school, we won't allow it.
Would that in your judgment be precluded by the judgment in this case?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Assuming you know what we are going to say.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: I guess that's--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I take it, I take it based on your position it's open to us to say that it's a violation of the establishment clause for the State to scan and to review every single event, every single class in order to purge it of religious content; that that is itself is an establishment violation.
That's open for us to say, so if we said, that would certainly foreclose the line of questioning that, the suggestions that Justice Souter is making about further lawsuits.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --Absolutely.
And moreover, Justice Kennedy, I think there is also this problem.

This is a broad community forum, and parents, it would seem to me the establishment clause was crafted to defend the rights of the religious people to participate in broad community forums and to exclude Andrea Fournier from a forum because of her religion would seem to be the very value that the establishment clause was, was crafted to defend, so if she wears her daisy scout uniform, for example, she is okay to come in, but if she wears her Good News Club uniform, she is not.

And it, I think not only the free speech clause protects her right to meet under those circumstances, but not to be excluded from a broad community forum and the parents not to be excluded from the broad community forum also is protected by the establishment.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right.
I want to make sure I understand your answer.

You are saying that if you win this case based upon the ground that the exclusion broadly of religious viewpoints is unconstitutional, is it your position that if they then redraw the policy more narrowly and say we are going to exclude Sunday school type of meetings held on the school grounds immediately after school, is it your position that they would be foreclosed by the judgment of this Court in this case from doing that?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: The way you state it, Justice Souter, absolutely.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, not if we rely simply on, on, on the First Amendment speech clause.
That, that's another option that we have.
We say it's simply violative of the First Amendment speech clause.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It's almost impossible for counsel to say what the effect of an opinion is going to be.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Trust me, Mr. Marcelle.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Also principles of res judicata involved that anything that was litigated or might have been litigated in a suit is barred.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Trust me, Mr. Marcelle, we can write this opinion so it does almost nothing.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may I reserve the balance of my time?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Marcelle.
Mr. Miller, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court, the issue before this Court today is whether a public school district may lawfully exclude a religious group from conducting adult led, adult sponsored and adult initiated prayer and worship services and religious instruction immediately at the end of the school day where these activities involved the youngest children.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well now, what difference does adult sponsored make?
I assume the Girl Scout meetings are adult sponsored.
What's the purpose of emphasizing that?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: The purpose of emphasizing that--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: All these things are adult sponsored.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Well, Justice O'Connor, except for the fact that we have the Equal Access Act which we submit that if Petitioner's position is accepted in this case, the Equal Access Act will become meaningless because then you will be able to have adult led and adult sponsored religious activities occurring in a school which the Equal Access Act would prohibit.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What Equal Access Act are you talking about?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: I'm talking about the Equal Access Act that was discussed by this Court in Murgens and--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The New York law?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You are referring to some New York law?
Some Federal law?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, Justice O'Connor, the Federal statute known as the Equal Access Act.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is that before us in this case?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: No, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I didn't think it was presented to us on that basis.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: No, it is not.

It is that, it is that the Federal law would allow, the Equal Access Act would allow adult, would not allow adult led or adult sponsored religious worship and activity in a school under any circumstances.
Whereas, if it were student initiated and student led at the secondary level, that would be permissible under Federal law and those restrictions have been upheld by this court in Murgens.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Right.
But what are the grades covered at the Milford Central School?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, it's kindergarten through sixth grade, so it's actually ages 5 to 12.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, it would be unusual, wouldn't it, for any meeting after school not to have an adult leader?
He wouldn't have a bunch of fourth graders in there talking by themselves.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Oh, absolutely.
Oh absolutely.
Absolutely, Mr. Chief Justice.
I emphasize that point only because of the fact that under Federal law under the Equal Access Act, this activity wouldn't be permitted.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I just ask on the equal access, I don't really have it in mind.
Does the Equal Access Act not require or does it prohibit the activity you are describing?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: It would prohibit the activity.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It prohibits it.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: At the elementary level, and it would prohibit the involvement of adult supervision.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Are you sure about that?
I, I thought it would simply not compel it.
It doesn't cover, it doesn't cover it except, you know, student led activity.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Justice Scalia, my understanding of the Act was that it specifically prohibited adult led and adult sponsored activities at the elementary level, which is the situation.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Wow.
Well, then it would raise the same problem as this raises?
So my question would be, we have a fairly... no prayer in school is a controversial policy, but it has one virtue.
The court's opinion is, the virtue is it's clear.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
So the rule is as the courts interpreted it, that school activities cannot involve prayer.

Well, isn't the corollary of that where there isn't school activities, it can involve prayer, and it can involve religious activities, and here we are after school, so the same clear rule would say you can't pray in school, but after school is different, and you can't discriminate against religion after school.
Now, I put that because that's, I'm putting it squarely.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I want to hear your answer.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And, and my, my thought is aimed at the clarity of such a rule that ordinary people can understand, in light of the basic principles underlying establishment on the one hand and free speech on the other.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, Justice Breyer.
Justice Breyer, we contend that this is, and I believe the parties have stipulated that this is a limited open forum.
And what we have attempted to do is consistent with State law we have attempted to exclude the subject matter of religion.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Exactly.
And the question is, after school--

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --People can talk about any subject matter, but not religion.
That sounds to me as if you are discriminating in free speech terms against religion.
And now my question is, why isn't that contrary to the Constitution?
It's after school.
It's not a school activity.
And it doesn't help me to talk about open forums or not open forums or whatever.
I want, I want to know what, what the principle is, what the theory is?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, the theory is, Justice Breyer, that we have set limits to exclude on a reasonable basis certain activities from occurring in the school.
Just as we exclude partisan political activities.
We exclude commercial activities.
And we exclude various other activities, the school system has made a decision that it wanted to exclude this activity from its forum.
Now, consistent with a decision, for example, in Cornelius vs. NAACP, where the issue of partisan political speech was excluded from a limited open forum.
We have acted similarly in this circumstance.
Because of concern about some of these establishments.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What, what do you do about the, our Lamb's Chapel decision?
It seems to me that the Court of Appeals here paid very little attention to Lamb's Chapel.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: I'm, I'm well aware of that, Mr. Chief Justice.

But I think that in part, and I, I'm not certain why the Second Circuit wrote the majority opinion it did, except for the, I can offer the Court this, and that is that in footnote two of the majority opinion, this Court indicated very clearly that it was not addressing the issue of worship services and Sunday school.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well that... yes, but as I understand it, as it has been represented to us, that wasn't the basis for the school district's exclusion here.
The basis, as I understand it, was what you just told Justice Breyer a moment ago, that the district had chosen to exclude religious discussion from those which were, were open.
And that's, that's a very different criterion from saying, we're excluding the use of the facilities just for religious worship.
Which was it?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, Justice Souter, I think perhaps the actions of the school district have been somewhat mischaracterized.

I believe that there is a letter in the record from the superintendent that had indicated precisely what they were excluding, and the letter from the superintendent to the Reverend indicated that uses consistent with Lamb's Chapel would be permitted, but that religious worship would be excluded under the description of this forum.
So it was not excluded because of a viewpoint.
It was excluded because the entire subject matter of religious worship was excluded from the forum.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Where is that letter in the record?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Your Honor, please look at the joint appendix H 1 to H 2.

There is reference there to the Lamb's Chapel decision of this Court indicating that the viewpoint, the viewpoint was... was not what was being excluded, rather it was the religious worship that was being excluded.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And was it religious worship which was the ground that you... you chose to stand on in the district court and in the argument before the Second Circuit?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Justice... Justice Souter, we advanced both.
For example, an examination of our answer would reveal that we raised the establishment clause as an affirmative defense.
But I believe it's the next to the last page of the district court opinion, and I could find it if the Court wishes.

The district court, for example, concluded that because we had found that the limited open forum was properly created and properly limited, it did not need to reach our establishment clause arguments or the establishment clause issue.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: On that, you think this letter is correct that hearing a Bible lesson and memorizing Scripture is the equivalent of religious worship?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Justice Scalia, yes, sir, I do.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And have you memorized the Declaration of Independence or the preamble of the Constitution, that's something other... what is that?
That's not thinking?
That's not training of any kind?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Justice Kennedy--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's not, that's not imparting a view on what our history means?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Oh, of course it is.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: We, we don't want you to know... be able to recite the First Amendment?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: We don't certainly contend that that was a full description, Justice Kennedy, of everything that was occurring.
Rather we have a full record that the district court and the court of appeals in both instances concluded that this was indeed religious worship.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, suppose it was.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And I'm just putting this to get your response.
It doesn't necessarily reflect what I'm thinking.
But social events, it doesn't say social discussion.
Civic events, recreational events.
Entertainment events.
I guess that includes chess club, dances.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It includes all kinds of activity.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So suppose you were to say any activity is fine, just one is not.
Religious activity is not.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: After school.
Now, my question is given Lamb's Chapel, why would that be constitutional?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, Justice Breyer, the premise of the question operates under the assumption that the only thing that we excluded was religious, were religious activities, I believe.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, that's what seems to be what you're saying.
What you excluded here, there is a separate section and it says the separate section, use for nonreligious purposes.
It says school premises shall not be used by any individual or organization for religious purposes.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So it seems to me that what you have on one side of the page is use it for anything, and on the other side of the page, there is an exception, religious purposes.

Now, my question, which has been throughout is, how do you square that with Lamb's Chapel, i.e., since its after school, and isn't a school activity, why isn't it discrimination against religion under the First Amendment?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Your Honor, we have excluded the entire subject matter of religion as we--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, doesn't that make it worse?
Every other subject matter is there.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, because that is not, that is, in fact, not the case as this particular forum was created.

This particular forum also excluded partisan political speech and various other activities that I believe we enumerated in our brief and I think are enumerated elsewhere in the record, particularly the deposition of the school superintendent identifies a number of those.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But, but it didn't exclude discussions of morality... the Boy Scouts, the Girl Scouts teach that.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What it really excluded was a discussion of morality that had a religious perspective.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, that... the facts in the case really don't spell that out.
And in fact, there is no development of the record in terms of what precisely the Boy Scouts did, other than recite the Boy Scout motto.
In fact, the record doesn't reflect that they actually held their typical club meetings on school premises.
What they actually held on school premises were leadership meetings and not actual Cub Scout--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, the very oath of the Boy Scouts is moral.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
And our position has been that that's essentially an incidental mention of those issues.
It is different from or distinct from religious worship.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And so someone who spoke of, wanted to teach about how to be a good citizen from a particularly, especially secular point of view could not have done so under your program?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Your Honor, they could have.
I believe that--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: They could have done it.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But someone who wanted to speak about exactly the same subject from a religious point of view could not have?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: I don't... I don't agree with the Chief Justice's statement of the question.
Your Honor, we would have allowed them to express their viewpoint on a secular subject, I believe consistent with Lamb's Chapel.
We would not have, however, permitted religious worship services, which is essentially what this was.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You say this is essentially a religious worship service.
Now, I think people might quarrel with that.

You can have, I think one of my colleagues here described it as more like Sunday school, and I think that's probably an accurate description, but it certainly isn't religious worship in the sense that most people think of it.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, except for the fact, Your Honor... Your Honor that the Sunday school is generally the way that religious worship is presented to children of this, of this age group.
They are typically not required to attend the full service and so forth.
They typically attend a Sunday school type service.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Another way to put it would be that children of that age don't engage in religious worship.
They go to Sunday school.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, Justice Scalia, they go--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, just because they go, you are going to suddenly convert Sunday school into a Mass?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --No.
Justice Scalia, except for the fact that what they do is that they, they engage in an activity that's age appropriate, and for those children--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Don't they pray--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Religious worship is not part of it.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Don't they pray?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Yes, sir, they do.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: May I ask to you clarify now something that Mr. Marcelle addressed as well.
You have said that you raised the establishment clause as an affirmative defense.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And that the district court said I'm not going to deal with it because I decide the case in your favor on another ground.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So it was raised, you raised it, but it wasn't decided.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: It seems to me that that's got to remain open.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I believe that it does.
I believe it's very much involved in this case.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Your position is that saying a prayer is religious worship and I assume then that any group which sought to meet on your school's property which opened its meeting with a prayer would be excluded, and you think that's in accord with Lamb's Chapel?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Religious worship would be excluded, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And you said in response to Justice Souter that saying a prayer is religious worship, right?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Justice Scalia--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right?
So no group admitted to this school program can say a prayer to open its meeting?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --I wouldn't necessarily say that, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You just did say it.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, I... the point I'm getting across is that the activities of the Good News Club were more than merely reciting one prayer.
There was much more involved in that which is fully developed in the record, and those activities were much more religious and much more in the nature of a religious worship service.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They were more religious, but they were not necessarily the same thing as a church religion... as a church worship service, teaching the Scripture, teaching what the Scripture has to say about morality.
I mean, I think it's a great distortion to call that a worship service.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Justice Scalia--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Even if you throw in a prayer or two.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Justice Scalia, for children of this age group, that is the religious worship service that they would typically engage in.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, if that's so--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --And that's what you want to litigate, if on the broad ground you lose, you say we have raised that, and we should be allowed to litigate that go back to district court, is that it?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: I'm hoping we don't lose this case, Justice Souter.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I recognize that, but you're saying, whether you agree with Justice Scalia or not, you're saying we want to litigate that in the district court and--

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: I believe that we've preserved it and fully developed the record with respect--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Well, you did litigate it, didn't you?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Except for the fact, Mr. Chief Justice, that it was not ruled on specifically.
The district court said because we've concluded that your limited open forum was constitutional under Second Circuit precedent, we didn't need to reach the establishment clause argument.
It was raised.
It was not, however, ruled on previously by the district court.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is that the right way, then, to deal with what I would see as the difficult issue in this case, the difficult issue being suppose it's a total prayer service?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Imagine that it is.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, is the way to get at that problem, if assuming there is a problem, that either a total prayer service would be unlawful, either you have... either it would violate the establishment clause or it wouldn't.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If it doesn't violate the establishment clause, you lose this case a fortiori.
If it does violate the establishment clause, then the way to get at it is through litigating the establishment clause issue.
I'm trying to figure out.
That's been the point of my question.

I'm trying to figure out how to do this on the assumption that this is pure prayer, which I know it isn't, because the other alternative you could argue whether it is or isn't, but assume it was, how do we get at that issue?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, several ways.

Number one, I think that even if it's not a... technically an establishment clause violation, I think the school district had a reasonable basis to conclude that it might potentially be disruptive, it might potentially be divisive of the community to allow this type of utilization of the school building, and out of concern that perhaps religions which did not predominate in the area might be unrepresented and unable to use the school facility for similar purposes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: This is divisive in the community?
I don't understand.
What would the community get upset about?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, Justice Scalia--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You would let all religious groups do this, right?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Presumably, if you ordered it.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Religious groups that didn't want to do it would get upset that other religious groups did want to do it?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, actually, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You must have a very divisive community down there.
I'm glad I don't live in New York anymore.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Actually it isn't terribly divisive, Justice Scalia.

What we are concerned about is, is that there may be religious groups that do not have a substantial representation in this small town community, and that the majority religion, such as Reverend Fournier represented would be able to run a Good News Club, but the other groups that didn't have the numbers or the personnel couldn't run a similar club, and that would show a favoritism to this particular club.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why would it be a favoritism?

I mean, presumably if they met the standards for, if you have to have a certain number of people come to the meeting, any religious group that met that standard would have been granted the same right, wouldn't they?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.
But it's--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, then what you're saying basically, it's kind of a heckler's veto, that if people don't like what the school is doing and are unhappy about it, that is a reason for excluding religion.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --I don't believe that to be the only basis upon which we've determined that it is appropriate to exclude this.

We have also relied, to some extent, upon the mandate of State law that the school is bound to follow, and may I point out, please, that in the complaint there is no challenge to the constitutionality of section 414 of the education law.

That relief was not asked for at the district court, it was not asked for at the court of appeals, and it is not, in my judgment, at least from what I read in the complaint, it is not before this Court.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, but are you contending that the State statute required this policy?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Justice Stevens, I believe that that's essentially what the State statute mandated.
The State statute, education... New York education law 414 prohibited use of a school building for religious purposes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, but you don't say that the school couldn't adopt some different policy and say we're not going to allow any use of our buildings at all?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That is correct, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The State law does not prohibit that?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And the school could say, we're only going to allow after school use for athletic purposes.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Or we're only going to allow it after 6 p.m..

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yeah.
It only sets a ceiling, whatever that State law is.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That is correct, except one of the things that they do not permit, along with other prohibitions, such as a political... partisan political activities, commercial activities, and so on.
One of the other excluded areas is a religious activity.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, Mr. Miller, you can't have it both ways.
If you say that the State law requires this--

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --then certainly the constitutionality of the State law is at issue in this case.
There is no difference whatever between saying that what the State law requires is unconstitutional and saying that the State statute is unconstitutional.
That's one and the same.
You can't have it both ways.
If you say the State statute requires this, we are passing upon the constitutionality of the State statute, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Just as you were in Lamb's Chapel, but the same statute was before the court in Lamb's Chapel, and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: By the way, the Federal Equal Access Act does not prohibit what was done here.
It does not contain any prohibitions.
It just says that the requirements which this Act imposes--

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --are not imposed upon elementary schools--

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: At the elementary level.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: My understanding is it was a very vigorous debate about whether--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It doesn't prohibit doing it at the elementary level.
It just says Federal law does not require you to do it at the elementary level.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --That is correct.
That is correct.
The... we contend that the establishment clause argument is very much involved in this case.

We did raise that as an affirmative defense in our answer, and we contend that if this particular use is permitted, we will have Sunday school on a Tuesday in a public school occurring at 3 o'clock immediately upon the end of the official school day.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, now, just a minute.
I thought we just went over this.
There is nothing in the world that prohibits the school from saying we're not going to have any activity before 6 p.m. or 3:30 or 4:00 or 5:00, whatever it is.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You told me the school can do that.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: The school can do that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So why would you complain about 3 o'clock?
That must be something the school itself set up.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That is correct, Justice O'Connor, it is something that the school set up and allows, but they didn't specify specific times, and when they examined this particular circumstance, they determined that it was religious worship and chose not to exclude it... or, excuse me, chose to exclude it.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --But that's all that's before us is the religious worship.
The school obviously can set the hours and the days and the opportunities for all these groups.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That is--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And your position is they can't do it at any time of day, and that's the way the case has been presented to us here.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --That is correct.
That is correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And the school, in fact, never complained about the time, none of this correspondence said the problem is you're doing it right after school and these other kids will think that... right?
That was never in any of this stuff?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That is correct, Justice Scalia, the original denial was based on the fact that it was religious worship, not based upon the specific time of day, that is correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And you defend that position?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Yes, sir, I do.

I believe we have the right to limit the forum to certain activities that the school believes have a reasonable basis consistent with the mission of the school system, and under the circumstances, as they have excluded other activities, such as political activities and commercial activities and similar activities, they are permitted to exclude these activities as well.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, why would it violate the establishment clause?

I mean, let's take an extreme case, a local church, which doesn't have a building, says, we would like to use the school for worship services two or three times a week at 4:00 in the afternoon to 6:00, all right?
So they do it.
And the school district says, no, this is a school, it's not a church.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Even after school.
Now why, I want to understand why... it may well.
Why does it violate the establishment clause, in your view?
After all, you could turn it into a gymnasium.
That's not the... this is not a discrimination point.
This is an establishment point.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Because under those circumstances that you just posit, I believe that the school is then lending support to a particular religious exercise or a particular religion.
Under the circumstances of this particular case, our case, we have an increase in active attendance at the meetings, we have the school being utilized in effect as a church.
And the same activity was conducted only months earlier at the church.
And under the circumstances, we submit, to permit the utilization for a church service, for a worship service, would involve the school in endorsing and supporting the that particular religion.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But the state provides, for example, crossing guards on Sundays at church services, and that is not thought... to facilitate people going to the church service, there's no other reason for it.
So long as it provides crossing guards wherever else there is need for crossing guards, this is not considered to be an establishment of religion.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So why if public facilities... and I don't... I know many schools that do it.
If they're willing to let their facilities be used for any public purpose--

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Uh huh.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --why must they exclude a religious purpose so long as they're doing it evenhandedly, all religions, all other purposes, just like crossing guards?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: The example of the crossing guards you gave, I presume, is on a public street.
That would be an open forum where restrictions and limitations would be very difficult to justify.

In the case of a limited open forum, such as the school district where you've previously... this Court has previously indicated we have to have special sensitivity to the age and so forth of the children, we believe that it's appropriate to make those judgments to exclude from the forum those activities that the school officials may believe are not inconsistent with the mission.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: On Sundays?
On Sundays and after the kids are gone?
The building's just lying there.
Actually the community can make money, it rents it out to any group that wants it.
The church needs it.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, they wouldn't... if they were doing it for a for profit purpose under New York law, that wouldn't be permissible.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh, you can violate the establishment clause for money?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, no, no, it wouldn't be a permissible use was my point.
It would not be permitted under the school use policy or under New York education law 414.
It's simply not permitted.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: To prohibit the use of public facilities for religious purposes shows the State is neutral as to religion, is that your point?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Justice Kennedy, I believe that we are required to be neutral and permit the schoolhouse to be used as a house of worship would violate, I believe, the principle of neutrality.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Why would it do so if, unlike this case, there's no particular involvement of schoolchildren involved, and the district allows the, let's say the auditorium to be used for a meeting of the Elks, for a meeting of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, and the Baptists have had their church burned, and they want to use it.

Why would... what would the theory be that would explain why it would be a violation of the establishment clause to let the church group use it on the same terms as the VFW and other secular organizations?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Is Justice Souter's question in reference to this specific record or is this a hypothetical?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, no, I'm going back I think to Justice Breyer's question, and I understood you to answer his question in such a way that would say, yes, it would, in my example, it would be a violation to let the church group use it at the same... on the same terms as the VFW, and I don't understand what your reasoning is.
What's the establishment clause theory that leads you to say that?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Because you would be permitting then a schoolhouse to be used as a house of worship.
In the case of... in our particular case, at 3 o'clock there are lots of other educational activities going on.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, if that was the case, in... the facts in Widmar, then, would have been an establishment clause violation because in Widmar you had a state university property that was being used for purposes of worship, so that would have violated the establishment clause.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Well, Justice Souter, I believe that Widmar is a totally different case.
Number one, it's an open forum as opposed to a limited open forum.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But you're talking about the First Amendment, and now we're talking about the establishment clause.

I take it, then, that given your answer to my question and Justice Breyer's, you would say that the student worship service in Widmar on university property was a violation of the establishment clause.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: I would have to take the position that with respect to that forum which had been open for all purposes--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: We're not talking about forum analysis.
We're talking about establishment clause analysis.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Uh huh.
Yes, sir, I understand.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: In other words, I'm going from the speech clause to the establishment clause.
Was the Widmar worship service on public property a violation of the establishment clause?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: This Court apparently held it wasn't, although you looked at it as a free speech case, so presumably--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --in that particular matter you allowed it.
In this circumstance--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: In this particular district, this school district, we're dealing with elementary grades?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: --Correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Is there any practice with respect to high school or public colleges in that area?
Do they have student groups that can meet for religious purposes as well as all others?

turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, that is not reflected in the record, and I'm not certain of the answer to that.
I believe, however, that the record reflects that there were no other religious uses that went on at this particular school, but the record is not developed on that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Does the record show that there are a lot of other children who were hanging around the school while this service is conducting... conducted?
Is that in the record?
