turn.speaker: frank_w_miller
turn.label: Mr. Frank W. Miller
turn.text: It is not fully developed, Justice Scalia, but I believe there is some evidence of that, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Miller.
Mr. Marcelle, you have five minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: If the Court... if it would please the Court, I have two quick points to make on rebuttal.
First, I believe there is a slight misstatement of the record.
At the cert petition, appendix H, page 6, it describes Milford School as a housing... building of both elementary, junior high, and high school.
The school building contains grades K-12, not just elementary school.
Second, with respect to the Equal Access Act, I believe Justice Scalia is right, it is only a mandate that Congress passed it.
If a high school did certain things, they would have to allow certain other high school groups.
There is nothing in the statute that makes it a prohibition to it, even in the absence of the law, to allow other groups.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Can I ask as long as... I would like you to--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --This is on rebuttal.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I thought he was finished.
Do you have something else?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: No, I'm finished, Justice.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I thought he was.
If you have an extra minute, I'd like just to get your view on what I'm finding is the most difficult part of this, which we may not reach.
To take the opponent's point on the establishment clause, suppose the city hall says every Sunday we can use the city hall as a church, we'll let church groups use it.
So every Sunday the city hall becomes a church.
Does that violate the establishment clause?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Not if it has a broad forum.
It would violate the statute--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, what they'll say is any group can use it.
Now, what happens is that every Sunday the city hall becomes a church and all the community goes there and gathers and prays.
Does that violate the establishment clause?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --I don't believe so, Justice Breyer.

I believe as long as the forum is open, the... and the State is neutral, that a reasonable observer would be aware of the policy and the history and the context of the situation and wouldn't view that the State was endorsing the religious ceremony, but, rather, the adherents who chose to avail themselves of the forum, the endorsement belongs really to the people who attend and not be accredited to the State as long as the State didn't really encourage or promote or recognize the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask you a factual question?
Does the record tell us how big the group was of the children involved in this club?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --How many, Justice Stevens?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Initially, at the time of making the application, there were 20, and we had opportunity to use the school for a year and a half, and at the conclusion of that, at the time we made our motion for summary judgment, I believe, it was the same number.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You used it for a year and a half.
You actually did use it before the prohibition was issued or what?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: The district court... yes, Justice Scalia, the district court issued an injunction, and we used the school facilities for a year and a half.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But you didn't use it?
At what time did you use it?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: At 3 o'clock, the high school resource room.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: At 3 o'clock.
And was there any evidence about whether other grammar school students were still milling about when you were using it, looking longingly at the classroom where this was going on?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: No, Justice Scalia.
In fact--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Go ahead.

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: --In fact, in the district court's opinion, and for the preliminary injunction, it says such a case would be unlikely.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You say this was the high school room?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: Yes, a high school resource room, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is the high school and the elementary school one facility?

turn.speaker: thomas_marcelle
turn.label: Mr. Thomas Marcelle
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Marcelle.
The case is submitted.
